questions.question: What is the main objective of the experiment involving thin layer chromatography (TLC)?

answers.a: To identify the solvent used in chromatography.
answers.b: To understand the principles of chromatographic techniques.
answers.c: To separate ink components based on their colours.
answers.d: To measure the thickness of the stationary phase.

questions.question: In thin layer chromatography (TLC), what is the purpose of the stationary phase?

answers.b: To serve as the mobile phase.
answers.d: To provide a surface for separation.

questions.question: How does chromatography separate components in a mixture?

answers.a: By using a single solvent with high polarity.
answers.b: By attracting all components to the mobile phase.
answers.c: By exploiting differences in polarity between components.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Rf value in TLC?

answers.a: To calculate the density of the solvent.
answers.c: To quantify the amount of stationary phase.
answers.d: To identify and compare components in a mixture.

questions.question: How does the choice of solvent polarity affect the separation of components in TLC?

answers.a: A more polar solvent results in better separation.
answers.b: A more polar solvent carries all components together.
answers.c: Solvent polarity has no effect on separation.
answers.d: A less polar solvent is ideal for separation.
